Hello everyone, sorry for cross-posting! As we are ramping up our DOL work, I would like ask you to contribute to our Curation sources document as you add content to this channel <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1cRJYAUtUSMactks3GsvlbQrA12W02zmyFbBnxXH55Ig/edit?usp=sharing>.

This document is to collect sources of content for our future MVPs.

If you know a particular website, newsletter, a person on Twitter, etc that are a great source of content on a certain topic, please add it under that topic in "Topic-specific sources".

"General" segment is for websites or people who might be a good source for a number of the identified topics.

Add a few keywords about the resource, so it is not just a link.

If you come across a specific resource that should be added to the next MVP, use this Airtable form to add it to the database <https://airtable.com/shrhxO1SMgk3eM6Pb>,  but if you have no time to add it to the database, add it under “Topic-specific resources for future MVPs”, so it does not get lost.

Thank you!

messages.text: Thanks for sharing, Richard! It didn't really touch on it but a major way to make things less biased or discriminatory in AI systems is to hire for more diversity in the people who design the systems. Diverse groups are more likely to recognize prejudice in training sets (e.g., when HP's laptop cameras could not identify minorities because the training set featured pics of only white people)

attachments.title: Tackling bias in artificial intelligence (and in humans)
attachments.text: In order to avoid bias in artificial intelligence, fair and transparent decisions will be needed to build confidence in AI systems.

attachments.title: Global AI Talent Report 2019 - jfgagne
attachments.text: Voir la version française Executive Summary There is strong evidence that the supply of top-tier AI talent does not meet the demand. Yet there is little visibility on precisely how scarce this talent is or where it is concentrated around the world. This report summarizes our second survey of the scope and breadth of the worldwide AI talent pool. Our research relies on three main data sources. First, to get a picture of the researchers who are moving the field forward, we reviewed the publications from 21 leading scientific conferences in the field of AI and analyzed the profiles of the authors. This expands upon our 2018 report, when we looked at just three conferences. Second, we analyzed the results of several targeted LinkedIn searches, which showed us how many individuals are self-reporting that they have doctorates as well as the requisite skills in different regions around the world. Finally, we looked to outside reports and other secondary sources to help us put our findings in context and better understand the talent pool in a rapidly changing global AI landscape. Our findings show that 22,400 people published at one or more of the top conferences in the field of machine...
attachments.fallback: jfgagne: Global AI Talent Report 2019 - jfgagne

attachments.title: Federal government opens 2 of 5 alternative work hubs for public servants
attachments.text:
The federal government announced Monday that it would be providing federal public servants with 385 work spaces across five sites in the National Capital Region, a move that Coun. Carol Anne Meehan says is a good start, but isn’t quite enough to entirely combat Ottawa’s growing issues with traffic congestion.
The pilot project, called GCcoworking, is being spearheaded by Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC) and seeks to provide federal government employees with flexible workplaces separate from their regular offices or homes.
Free to use, the stations will be open from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. on weekdays. Employees can either reserve them ahead of time online or just drop in.


This Touchdown Area is a new swing space at L’Esplanade Laurier.



This Touchdown Area is a new swing space at L’Esplanade Laurier.

“We have a vision where we would like any public servant to be able to work anywhere, any time,” says Sonia Powell, director general of Workplace Solutions at PSPC. “It’s a concept for what future work will look like in federal public service.”
Two of the five hub sites, L’Esplanade Laurier in Centretown and 335 River Rd. in the south end, officially opened their doors to employees on Monday. Other locations at Place d’Orléans, 555 Legget Dr. in Kanata and 480 boulevard de la Cité in Gatineau are to open in August.
“When we selected the sites, we chose one central location as a convenient meeting place (so) people from several departments (can) come together,” says Powell, who has been working with the GCcoworking concept for three years. “We also located them in the suburbs … so that people could have an option that’s closer to home.”


The new GGcoworking includes 55 spaces at 335 River Rd.



The new GGcoworking includes 55 spaces at 335 River Rd.

Meehan sees an added benefit from the hubs, saying they will “absolutely” ease traffic congestion in the region.
“One of my campaign promises was a solution to our congestion mess … We don’t have the money to put in roads and new rapid bus routes. The only thing we can do is make it easier for people to leave their cars at home,” Meehan says. “The majority of the traffic out here are people driving their cars to get into the federal, provincial and city government offices.”


Yea. Feds opening up mini work hub in its offices at 335 River Road for employees in the south end who don’t want to commute downtown. Book a spot, plug in and work. Limited space but it’s a start!!  Need more of this to ease congestion. #ottawa #ottnews 
— Carol Anne Meehan (@MeehanCarolAnne) May 14, 2019

The hubs will remove some federal public servants from the traffic equation, but the remaining problem is in their capacity. The Gatineau location is the largest, with 99 spots, while 335 River Rd., in Meehan’s ward, Gloucester-South Nepean, is the smallest with 55.
“It’s a start,” Meehan said. “We need a heck of a lot more than that out here.”
Of course, this remains a pilot project for now, with each location to be operational for two years.
Powell is optimistic.
“We’re hopeful … that people will want to have more,” she says. “I think people are going to use them because they’re interested in working differently and having access to modern spaces.”


This photo shows a Focus Pod, one of the new features of the GGcoworking pilot project.



This photo shows a Focus Pod, one of the new features of the GGcoworking pilot project.

Powell says public servants will first come to the hubs because they’re curious, but they’ll come back because of their unique features, including adjustable sit-stand desks, Focus Pods for privacy and Touchdown Areas designed for employees to quickly check emails or charge mobile phones.
“These sites are fully equipped with all the technology you need, and sometimes your own home (or typical workspace) doesn’t have (all that),” Powell says.
Meehan wants everyone on board for additional hubs.
“I want everybody to be going to their employers and saying, ‘The congestion that I face everyday is getting worse … It’s impacting my health because I’m sitting in cars for an hour and a half every day. Is there something we can do … to establish something where we can work closer to home?’ Everybody’s got to push for this.”
ALSO IN THE NEWS: 
New hospital information system has potential to ‘save lives,’ chief of staff says
Tornadoes strike in east end of Ottawa area
Military may be asked to return to help remove sandbags after floods subside

							This embed is invalid" />
attachments.fallback: Ottawa Citizen Link: Federal government opens 2 of 5 alternative work hubs for public servants

attachments.title: Performing a Project Premortem
attachments.text: Projects fail at a spectacular rate. One reason is that too many people are reluctant to speak up about their reservations during the all-important planning phase. By making it safe for dissenters who are knowledgeable about the undertaking and worried about its weaknesses to speak up, you can improve a project’s chances of success. Research […]

messages.text: Google's remote teams playbook found in a resource that Todd shared: <http://services.google.com/fh/files/blogs/distributedworkplaybooks.pdf>

In the first article, I appreciated the nuances and honestly I need to re-read it. What surprised me was how the author looked at digital engagement, and the different types of questions for redesign.

From the second article "What a Digital Organization Looks Like" I found this interesting...

"From what we’ve learned so far, we think there are five main aspects of a digital organisation, and you ideally need all of them to be in place.

1) Environment — understand what changes are taking place
2) Users — put them at the heart of your organisation
3) Workforce — empowered, equipped and organised to work digitally
4) Leadership — bold, open, curious
5) Tech, data and processes — flexible, to serve your organisation’s goals"

Specifically, I thought that users resonated with the team meeting on May 9th.
